questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with familial hypercholesterolemia, physicians are discussing the mechanisms of cholesterol uptake in cells. Which process among the following, relevant to cholesterol transport into cells, does not typically follow saturation kinetics in its uptake?
Gap junctions are intercellular connections that

options.label: A
options.text: Primarily serve to keep cells separated and allow for transport across a tissue barrier.

options.label: B
options.text: Serve as a regulated cytoplasmic bridge for sharing of small molecules between cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Serve as a barrier to prevent protein movement within the cellular membrane.

options.label: D
options.text: Are cellular components for constitutive exocytosis that occurs between adjacent cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Serve as a regulated cytoplasmic bridge for sharing of small molecules between cells.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) serve as a regulated cytoplasmic bridge for sharing of small molecules between cells.

questions.text: In a study, researchers were assessing the efficacy of the baroreceptor reflex in maintaining blood pressure homeostasis. A healthy volunteer undergoes a positional change from lying to standing, resulting in an initial drop in systolic blood pressure by 20 mm Hg. Subsequently, the baroreceptor reflex partially compensates, restoring 16 mm Hg. What is the gain of the baroreceptor system in this scenario?
The electrogenic Na+/K+-ATPase plays a critical role in cellular physiology by:

options.label: A
options.text: Using the energy in ATP to extrude 3 Na+ out of the cell in exchange for taking two K + into the cell.

options.label: B
options.text: Using the energy in ATP to extrude 3 K+ out of the cell in exchange for taking two Na + into the cell.

options.label: C
options.text: Using the energy in moving Na+ into the cell or K + outside the cell to make ATP.

options.label: D
options.text: Using the energy in moving Na+ outside of the cell or K+ inside the cell to make ATP.

questions.correct_answer: A. Using the energy in ATP to extrude 3 Na+ out of the cell in exchange for taking two K + into the cell.
questions.explanation: Ans. A) using the energy in ATP to extrude 3 Na+ out of the cell in exchange for taking two K + into the cell.

questions.text: Second messengers

options.label: A
options.text: Are substances that interact with first messengers outside cells.

options.label: B
options.text: Are substances that bind to first messengers in the cell membrane.

options.label: C
options.text: Are hormones secreted by cells in response to stimulation by another hormone.

options.label: D
options.text: Mediate the intracellular responses to many different hormones and neurotransmitters.

questions.correct_answer: D. Mediate the intracellular responses to many different hormones and neurotransmitters.
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Mediate the intracellular responses to many different hormones and neurotransmitters.

questions.text: 30-year-old male the different body fluid compartments were measured. Which of the following can be used to measure his extracellular fluid volume?

In the context of endocrine disorders, the abundant presence of smooth endoplasmic reticulum within endocrine cells plays a pivotal role. A prolific system of smooth endoplasmic reticulum is present in endocrine cell acting through which one of the following?
Identify the type of the transport shown in the diagram below.

A 32-year-old male presents with acute onset of profuse watery diarrhea described as resembling “rice water” or rice gruel. He recently returned from a coastal region in south asia. He appears dehydrated, and stool cultures are pending. The physician suspects a bacterial toxin that increases intestinal permeability. Which of the following cellular structures is most likely impaired, leading to the patient's symptoms?
Channels in the cell membrane are formed from:

Which of the following statements regarding body fluid compartments is/are correct? Intracellular fluid makes up 40% of body weight. Interstitial fluid accounts for 15% of body weight. Plasma contributes to 10% of body weight. Total body water is approximately 60% of body weight
The dihydropyridine receptors located in the skeletal muscle are?
Which of the following is incorrect with respect to resting membrane potential in different cell types:

A 65-year-old man with chronic kidney disease presents with edema and hypoalbuminemia. His lab results indicate electrolyte imbalances, including increased sodium and chloride retention. The clinician explains that the presence of non-diffusible plasma proteins (e.g., albumin) inside blood vessels influences the distribution of electrolytes across the capillary membrane. Which of the following principles best explains this phenomenon?
A small change in the plasma concentration of which of the following ions is most likely to have the greatest impact on the membrane potential of cardiac muscle cells even at rest?

In a patient exhibiting neurological symptoms characterized by an impairment in the positive feedback loop crucial for neuronal depolarization, the failure to reach the firing or threshold level (-55 mv) is attributed to an underlying ion channel dysfunction. Which ion channelopathy would be most likely responsible for this specific impairment?

options.label: B
options.text: Dysfunction of the sodium potassium pump

questions.text: Which curve among the following represents the production of beta-globin chains?
In the given figure, at which labeled point on the action potential is the relative refractory period located?

The neurologist suspects a nerve injury due to the trauma and considers the type of nerve damage that could occur when the nerve fiber is disrupted but the surrounding sheath remains intact, facilitating potential nerve regeneration. Identify the type of nerve injury.

A 28-year-old athlete is performing high-intensity weightlifting exercises. During muscle contraction, the power stroke movement is responsible for shortening of the sarcomere. For generation of this movement which of the following muscle proteins is required which also forms the A band?
Pressure in the urinary bladder falls drastically at the time of voiding but rises back to normal in few minutes . This property of smooth muscle is known as :

A 25-year-old man is participating in a study on skeletal muscle physiology. During muscle fiber stimulation, which of the following represents the correct sequence of events involved in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle?

options.label: A
options.text: Action potential in muscle fiber → Neuromuscular junction activation → Calcium release → T-tubule activation → Contraction

options.label: B
options.text: Neuromuscular junction activation → Action potential in muscle fiber → T-tubule propagation → Calcium release from cisternae → Contraction

options.label: C
options.text: Calcium binds to actin → Action potential spreads → Calcium released → Neuromuscular stimulation → Muscle contracts

options.label: D
options.text: Action potential in T-tubule → Muscle contraction → Calcium released → Action potential in cisternae → Relaxation

questions.correct_answer: B. Neuromuscular junction activation → Action potential in muscle fiber → T-tubule propagation → Calcium release from cisternae → Contraction
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Neuromuscular junction activation → Action potential in muscle fiber → T-tubule propagation → Calcium release from cisternae → Contraction

questions.text: Which of the following types of stimuli produces only a local potential, but not an action potential?
Relaxation of muscle occurs by involving all of the following mechanisms except :

options.label: A
options.text: Hydrolysis of ATP in the myosin

options.label: B
options.text: Removal of Ca²⁺ from troponin C

options.label: C
options.text: Attachment of ATP to the myosin head

options.label: D
options.text: Active pumping of Ca²⁺ into the cisternae

questions.correct_answer: A. Hydrolysis of ATP in the myosin
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Hydrolysis of ATP in the myosin

questions.text: Match the following types of nerve injuries with their corresponding descriptions: Column a (type of nerve injury): Neuropraxia Axonotmesis Neurotmesis Sunderland’s 3rd-degree injury Sunderland’s 4th-degree injury Column b (description): Axon, endoneurium and perineurium are damaged, but epineurium is intact Temporary loss of nerve function without structural damage Axon and endoneurium are damaged, but perineurium and epineurium remain intact Complete loss of nerve function with irreparable damage to all structures Axon is damaged, but connective tissues remain intact

A 32-year-old male presents with progressive muscle weakness, difficulty chewing, and drooping eyelids. His symptoms worsen by the end of the day and improve after rest. Repetitive nerve stimulation testing shows a decremental response. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 68-year-old man presents with episodes of bradycardia. Ecg shows sinus node dysfunction. Pacemaker cells in the sinoatrial node generate rhythmic action potentials due to an unstable resting membrane potential. Which of the following events is not involved in the generation of the pacemaker potential?

Preload is the stretching of the cardiac muscle fibres at the end of diastole, just before contraction. It is due to an increase in ventricular pressure caused by the filling of blood during diastole. An image is provided below that further supplements the findings stated above. These are expressions of?

A 35-year-old man is undergoing a cardiovascular stress test. During exercise, his oxygen consumption increases significantly, leading to an enhanced cardiac output and redistribution of blood flow. Which of the following changes is least likely to occur in response to the increased metabolic demand?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased venous return due to muscle pump action

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased splanchnic blood flow due to sympathetic vasoconstriction

options.label: C
options.text: Increased coronary blood flow mediated by local metabolic vasodilation

options.label: D
options.text: Increased total peripheral resistance (TPR) due to widespread vasoconstriction

questions.correct_answer: D. Increased total peripheral resistance (TPR) due to widespread vasoconstriction
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Increased total peripheral resistance (TPR) due to widespread vasoconstriction

questions.text: Isovolumetric relaxation phase ends with:
Regarding various cardiovascular reflexes, which of the following is incorrectly matched with its description?

options.label: A
options.text: Bezold-Jarisch reflex – Bradycardia and hypotension due to stimulation of ventricular chemoreceptors; afferent and efferent limbs via vagus nerve.

options.label: B
options.text: Bainbridge reflex – Bradycardia due to increased venous return, mediated by stretch receptors in the right atrium.

options.label: C
options.text: Cushing reflex – Protective response to cerebral ischemia involving systemic hypertension and reflex bradycardia.

options.label: D
options.text: J reflex – Bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea due to stimulation of juxta-pulmonary capillary (j) receptors.

questions.correct_answer: B. Bainbridge reflex – Bradycardia due to increased venous return, mediated by stretch receptors in the right atrium.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Bainbridge reflex – Bradycardia due to increased venous return, mediated by stretch receptors in the right atrium.

questions.text: A mean blood pressure < 60 mmHg is detected by _______________ in the common carotid arteries and leads to a _______________ reflex that stimulates an increase in the heart rate and force of contraction.

A 66-year-old man with a history of severe aortic stenosis is evaluated for worsening exertional dyspnea. Aortic jet velocity on doppler echocardiography is significantly elevated. The cardiologist suspects turbulent blood flow across the narrowed valve. Which of the following parameters, if increased, would most significantly decrease the reynolds number in this patient?
Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with the shift of the pressure-volume loop?
Stimulating the cephalic end of a vagus nerve would causes the respiration to:

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease in depth because of the lung stretch receptor reflex

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in rate because of the increased activity of the dorsal respiratory group

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in depth because of the increased sympathetic activity

questions.correct_answer: A. Decrease in depth because of the lung stretch receptor reflex
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Decrease in depth because of the lung stretch receptor reflex

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is undergoing pulmonary function testing. During the test, he is asked to sit quietly and breathe normally without any forced effort. Which of the following muscles is primarily active during the expiratory phase of this quiet breathing?
All of the following can be seen in lower motor neuron lesions, except?

A 35-year-old patient presents with coordination difficulties and unsteady gait, suggesting potential involvement of the cerebellar hemispheres involved in planning of movement. In the context of this patient's symptoms and the cerebellum, which of the following structures represents the most lateral part of the cerebellar hemispheres?

A 36-year-old man at high altitude is undergoing an evaluation of his gas exchange parameters. At the alveolar level, oxygen binds to hemoglobin, leading to enhanced release of carbon dioxide from the blood into the alveolar space for exhalation. Which of the following physiological principles best explains this observation?

A 68-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with worsening dyspnea. Arterial blood gas analysis shows hypoxemia despite normal ventilation. Pulmonary function tests reveal increased physiological dead space. Which of the following best explains this finding?

A 62-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with progressive dyspnea. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals chronic hypercapnia and mild hypoxemia. Over time, his respiratory drive has shifted to become more dependent on oxygen levels rather than carbon dioxide levels. Which of the following receptors is primarily responsible for his respiratory drive?

options.label: B
options.text: Peripheral chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies

options.label: C
options.text: Stretch receptors in the lung parenchyma

questions.correct_answer: B. Peripheral chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Peripheral chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies

questions.text: Airway resistance is increased by all of the following except :
A patient has a dead space of 150 mL, FRC of 3L, tidal volume (TV) of 650 mL, ERV of 1.5L, TLC of 8L, and a respiratory rate of 15 breaths/min. What is the alveolar ventilation (VA)?
Which of the following best describes total lung capacity (TLC)?

options.label: A
options.text: The amount of air exhaled after a normal tidal expiration

options.label: B
options.text: The volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximal expiration

options.label: C
options.text: The maximum amount of air the lungs can hold

options.label: D
options.text: The volume of air exchanged during normal breathing

questions.correct_answer: C. The maximum amount of air the lungs can hold
questions.explanation: Ans. C) The maximum amount of air the lungs can hold

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is participating in a controlled metabolic study. Her oxygen consumption is measured at 300 ml/min, and her carbon dioxide output is recorded as 270 ml/min. What is the estimated respiratory quotient (RQ) in this individual?
The graph given below shows the normal FEV1 and FVC curves for a normal lung and a diseased lung. The abnormal graph represents which of the following?:

A 10-year-old boy presents with chronic cough, recurrent respiratory infections, and failure to thrive . Sweat chloride testing confirms a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. The underlying defect in this condition primarily affects which of the following physiological processes?

options.label: B
options.text: Chloride ion transport across epithelial membranes

questions.correct_answer: B. Chloride ion transport across epithelial membranes
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Chloride ion transport across epithelial membranes

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the rise in blood pressure during the early phase of the valsalva maneuver?

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure

questions.correct_answer: C. Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

questions.text: The figure shows three different compliance curves (s, t, and u) for isolated lungs subjected to various transpulmonary pressures. Which of the following best describes the relative compliances for the three curves?
With a slow decrease in left heart function, which of the following will minimize the formation of pulmonary edema?

options.label: A
options.text: An increase in plasma protein concentration due to fluid loss

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in the negative interstitial hydrostatic pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Increase in the concentration of interstitial proteins

questions.text: The following flow volume curve indicates:

During a medical physiology lecture, the professor discusses the concept of A-v (arterial-venous) oxygen difference and its variations in different types of hypoxia. The students are asked to identify the type of hypoxia in which the least A-v oxygen difference is observed.
The figure shows forced expirations from a person with healthy lungs (curve X) and from a patient (curve Z). The patient most likely has which condition?
Which of the following occurs during atelectasis of one lung?

options.label: C
options.text: Normal blood flow in the lung with atelectasis

questions.correct_answer: D. Slight decrease in arterial content
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Slight decrease in arterial content

questions.text: The MEFV curves shown in the above figure were obtained from a healthy person (red curve) and a 57-year-old man with shortness of breath (green curve). The man with shortness of breath likely has which disorder?
Which of the following occur during the beginning cough reflex?

options.label: A
options.text: Forced expiration against a closed glottis

options.label: B
options.text: Forced expiration against an open glottis

options.label: C
options.text: Forced inspiration against a closed glottis

questions.correct_answer: A. Forced expiration against a closed glottis
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Forced expiration against a closed glottis

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is diagnosed with myasthenia gravis. She is referred to a pulmonologist for a pulmonary function test. Spirometry reveals that her pulmonary volumes are normal. Based on her spirometry, at which of the following lung volumes will the expiratory muscles have the greatest force:
A man inspires 1000 ml from a spirometer. The intrapleural pressure was −4 cm H2O before Inspiration and −12 cm H2O the end of inspiration. What is the compliance of the lungs?
Fetal hemoglobin has higher affinity for oxygen due to:

options.label: D
options.text: Oxygen dissociation curve is shifted to right

questions.text: A 36-old man with end stage kidney disease has anemia (deficiency of RBCs). Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy?

A 25-year-old medical student undergoes an EEG recording. Initially, he is asked to remain alert with his eyes open, followed by a period where he closes his eyes and relaxes. The EEG shows a transition from high-frequency, low-amplitude waves to lower-frequency waves originating in the occipital cortex and thalamus. Which EEG wave pattern is most likely observed when his eyes are closed but he remains awake?

Which one of the following statement accurately describes the a neurological phenomenon commonly observed in motor control and pivotal in maintaining appropriate muscle tension, involves a specific neuronal pathway with interneuronal processing between sensory and motor neurons, regulating muscle contraction by modulating motor neuron activity based on Golgi tendon organ input?

options.label: A
options.text: Occurs when ia spindle afferents are inhibited.

options.label: B
options.text: Is a monosynaptic reflex initiated by activation of the golgi tendon organ.

options.label: C
options.text: Is a disynaptic reflex with a single interneuron inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs.

options.label: D
options.text: Uses type II afferent fibers from the golgi tendon organ

questions.correct_answer: C. Is a disynaptic reflex with a single interneuron inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs.
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Is a disynaptic reflex with a single interneuron inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs.

questions.text: Given the importance of muscle spindles in proprioception and reflex regulation, which of the following nerve fibers is primarily responsible for the motor supply to the intrafusal muscle fibers within these spindles?
Maximum area in homunculus signifies which one of the following?

A 32-year-old woman with a history of chronic pain syndrome is being evaluated in a pain management clinic. Her treatment regimen includes medications that modulate neurotransmitter levels to manage her pain. Considering the interaction between neurotransmitters and neuropeptides involved in pain modulation, what will be the effect of serotonin on the secretion of enkephalin?

options.label: C
options.text: No effect on the secretion of enkephalin

questions.correct_answer: A. Increases the secretion of enkephalin
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Increases the secretion of enkephalin

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with recent weight gain and increased appetite is found to have elevated agouti-related peptide (AgRP) levels in the hypothalamus. Which of the following best explains the physiological effect of increased AgRP activity?

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased food intake via stimulation of the anorexigenic pathway

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibition of melanocortin receptors, leading to increased appetite

options.label: D
options.text: Activation of the satiety center in the hypothalamus

questions.correct_answer: C. Inhibition of melanocortin receptors, leading to increased appetite
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Inhibition of melanocortin receptors, leading to increased appetite

questions.text: A 28-year-old man visits the clinic for a routine checkup. During the neurological examination, you assess his sensory perception. The patient is able to sense skin stretching and responds appropriately to joint position changes. These sensory modalities are primarily mediated by mechanoreceptors located in the skin and joints. Which of the following mechanoreceptors is most likely responsible for detecting skin stretch and contributing to joint movement in this patient?
A 40-year-old man was admitted to the emergency department following a traumatic injury. He is diagnosed with Brown-Séquard syndrome. Which of the following can be expected in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of proprioception on the ipsilateral side

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of vibration sense on the contralateral side

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of pain sensation on the ipsilateral side

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of fine touch on the contralateral side

questions.correct_answer: A. Loss of proprioception on the ipsilateral side
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Loss of proprioception on the ipsilateral side

questions.text: A 72-year-old man visits his physician because he finds it difficult to hold his hand steady when painting. Examination reveals a resting tremor and rigidity. The symptoms are relieved by a single dose of levodopa. This patient’s neurological signs are most likely related to a lesion within which of the following?
A motorcyclist suffered head injury 6 months back and presents with persistent memory deficits following injury. Choose the most appropriately matched option related to memory?

A gardener was accidentally poisoned by a weed killer that inhibits acetylcho-linesterase. Which of the following alterations in neurochemical transmission at brain cholinergic synapses is the most likely result of this poisoning?

options.label: B
options.text: A pileup of choline outside the cholinergic neuron (in the synaptic cleft)

options.label: C
options.text: A pileup of acetylcholine outside the cholinergic neuron (in the synaptic cleft)

questions.correct_answer: C. A pileup of acetylcholine outside the cholinergic neuron (in the synaptic cleft)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) A pileup of acetylcholine outside the cholinergic neuron

questions.text: A 27-year-old hiker becomes dehydrated after being lost in the desert for 24 hours without water. On examination, he has dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor, and concentrated urine. Which of the following renal mechanisms is most likely responsible for his body conserving water in this situation?

options.label: A
options.text: Insertion of aquaporin-2 channels in the proximal tubule

options.label: B
options.text: Increased sodium excretion by the thick ascending limb

options.label: C
options.text: Insertion of aquaporin-2 channels in the collecting duct

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased urea recycling in the medulla

questions.correct_answer: C. Insertion of aquaporin-2 channels in the collecting duct
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Insertion of aquaporin-2 channels in the collecting duct

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with dehydration is evaluated for his kidney’s ability to concentrate urine. The nephron segment responsible for creating a hyperosmotic medullary gradient by actively transporting sodium while being impermeable to water plays a key role in this process. Which part of the nephron functions as the countercurrent multiplier?

A 58-year-old man with nephrotic syndrome presents with generalized edema. Laboratory findings show low serum albumin levels. The physician explains that a structure within the capillary wall plays a crucial role in maintaining selective permeability and preventing excessive leakage of plasma proteins. Which of the following structures is responsible for this selective permeability?

A 25-year-old male presents with excessive thirst, polyuria, and fatigue. Blood glucose levels are normal. Further workup reveals hypernatremia, low urine osmolarity, and failure to concentrate urine after water deprivation. Which hormone dysfunction is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

A 58 years old man was brought to the emergency with confusion and lethargy. His temperature is 36.7 C, blood pressure is 86/58 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, and respirations are 10/min. pH is 7.59, pCO2 49 mmHg and P02 of 85mm Hg. Which of the following condition best describe his acid base status?
Which of the following is true regarding creatinine clearance?

options.label: A
options.text: Creatinine clearance is equal to inulin clearance.

options.label: B
options.text: Creatinine clearance is greater than inulin clearance.

options.label: C
options.text: Creatinine clearance is lesser than inulin clearance.

questions.correct_answer: B. Creatinine clearance is greater than inulin clearance.
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Creatinine clearance is greater than inulin clearance.

questions.text: Match the following urinary buffers with their functions: Column A (Urinary Buffer) Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) Ammonia (NH₃) Phosphate (PO₄³⁻) Column B (Function) Acts as the main titratable buffer in the collecting duct Primary buffer in the renal tubular system Inducible buffer that increases in response to acid load

A 35-year-old man with recurrent kidney stones undergoes a metabolic evaluation, which reveals elevated concentrations of various solutes in his urine. Which of the following solutes does not decrease in concentration as filtrate flows through the proximal convoluted tubule?

A 65-year-old patient presents with edema in the lower extremities. The attending physician explains to the medical students that fluid movement across capillaries is influenced by various pressures. Which of the following pressures when increased, primarily forces fluid out of the capillaries?

A 40-year-old woman presents with symptoms of severe hypertension and is suspected to have a renal origin for her condition. Imaging studies and kidney biopsy reveal abnormalities localized to the medulla of the kidney. Which of the following structures is least likely to be involved, given its primary location is outside the medulla?
Which of the following statements are incorrect about vasopressin?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a more powerful vasoconstrictor than angiotensin II.

options.label: B
options.text: Concentration of circulating blood vasopressin after severe hemorrhage can increase enough to attenuate reductions in arterial pressure markedly.

options.label: C
options.text: Uses adenylyl cyclase-cAMP as well as phospholipase c system.

options.label: D
options.text: Secreted by paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus

questions.correct_answer: D. Secreted by paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Secreted by paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance . Laboratory findings reveal low T3 and T4 levels with low TSH . Dysfunction of which of the following cell types is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
Which of the following second messengers helps in explaining the mechanism of action of leptin?

A 30-year-old female patient experiencing irregular menstrual cycles and seeking guidance from her healthcare provider. During the healthcare team explores factors influencing reproductive hormone regulation. Which of the following have a role in controlling the secretion of prolactin?

A 42-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, weight gain, and swelling in his neck. Physical examination reveals a significantly enlarged thyroid gland. His blood tests show decreased levels of T3 and T4. Which of the following best describes the function of thyroid peroxidase in thyroid hormone synthesis?

The process of insulin release in response to elevated blood glucose levels represents a finely tuned physiological mechanism critical for maintaining metabolic equilibrium. The phenomena of glucose mediated insulin release involves:

A 48-year-old man with peptic ulcer disease is prescribed a drug that selectively blocks histamine H2 receptors to reduce gastric acid secretion. Which of the following best explains how this drug exerts its effect on parietal cells?

options.label: A
options.text: It inhibits gastrin release from g cells

options.label: B
options.text: It blocks adenylate cyclase and reduces camp levels

options.label: C
options.text: It inhibits proton pump activity directly

options.label: D
options.text: It increases prostaglandin synthesis to inhibit acid secretion

questions.correct_answer: B. It blocks adenylate cyclase and reduces camp levels
questions.explanation: Ans. B) It blocks adenylate cyclase and reduces camp levels

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient undergoing evaluation for a suspected catecholamine-secreting tumor the healthcare team, into a comprehensive discussion on the principal metabolite resulting from norepinephrine metabolism and subsequently excreted in urine and the clinical implications of measuring this metabolite in the context of diagnosing and managing catecholamine-secreting tumors. The metabolite is

A 54-year-old female patient presents to her primary care physician for a routine check-up. She mentions that she has been following a diet low in calcium for several months due to personal preferences. The physician orders a series of laboratory tests. Based on the patient's dietary history and the body's physiological response to low calcium levels, which of the following laboratory findings would be most expected in this patient?

A 60-year-old man with hypertension is being evaluated for his medication regimen. His treatment includes an ace inhibitor to control his blood pressure. Which organ is the primary source of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)?
A 28-year-old breastfeeding mother complains of experiencing cramping in her breasts while nursing her infant. Which hormone is most likely responsible for this symptom?

A 60-year-old man presents with dry mouth and difficulty swallowing. His physician explains that salivary composition varies under different conditions. Under basal (unstimulated) conditions, which ion is present at the highest concentration in saliva?
The autonomic nervous system (ANS) is involved in the following functions except:
A 45-year-old woman eats a meal . Shortly after, her gallbladder contracts to release bile into the duodenum. Which of the following factors is the primary stimulus for gallbladder contraction?

A 45-year-old woman presents with chronic diarrhea and weight loss. Laboratory evaluation reveals fat malabsorption. Further testing demonstrates low levels of pancreatic enzyme activity despite normal pancreatic structure. A deficiency of which of the following gastrointestinal hormones is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?

Match the following - gastric cell secretions Column a (cells) Surface cells Parietal cells Enterochromaffin cells Chief cells G cells (in antrum) Column b (secretions) Gastric acid and intrinsic factor Pepsinogen Gastrin Histamine (increases acid secretion) Mucous (bicarbonate-rich) to neutralize acid

A 45-year-old male presents with epigastric pain, bloating, and early satiety. He has a history of chronic NSAID use for osteoarthritis. An upper Gi endoscopy reveals multiple gastric ulcers with a low ph in the gastric lumen. Which of the following secretions has the lowest ph?

A 60-year-old woman undergoes surgery that includes complete resection of the ileum and partial resection of the jejunum due to crohn's disease. What is the most likely side effect she is experiencing?
Which one of the following are used in calculating the serum osmolarity? 1. Serum sodium 2. Glucose 3. Calcium 4. Blood urea nitrogen
